statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: Colorado 64, Missouri 62
article.story: BOULDER, Colo. (AP) -- Walking toward the winning locker room, a veteran teammate draped his arm over Richard Roby's head and yelled, "That's what I'm talking about!" Everyone at Colorado knew it was just a matter of time before Roby did something big. It happened Wednesday night, when the freshman guard hit a 3-pointer with 21 seconds left to lift the Buffaloes to a 64-62 win over Missouri. "I saw my defender's hands were down and seized the opportunity and I shot it," Roby said. "Thank God it went in." Roby, the half-brother of Denver Nuggets forward Kenyon Martin, dribbled a couple times, took a step inside the 3-point line to create room between himself and the defender, then stepped back behind the line and swished the game-winner. It gave Colorado (10-7, 2-4 Big 12) a modest, two-game winning streak and a much-needed shot of momentum after a losing four straight to start the conference season. The teammate who offered the congratulations, Andy Osborn, knew Roby's feeling. Osborn hit the game-winner four nights previous in a 54-52 overtime victory at Iowa State. "Any time we don't have to depend on one person to make a shot for us when we need one speaks volumes," coach Ricardo Patton said. Seconds after Roby's shot, Jason Horton of Missouri (10-9, 2-4 Big 12) had a look at a 3-pointer that would have given the Tigers the lead, but he missed. Marcus Hall of Colorado rebounded Horton's miss and fed to Jayson Obazuaye, who was fouled and missed two free throws with 1.3 seconds left. The Buffs rebounded the miss and ran out the clock, however, and Missouri fell to 0-6 away from home this season. "I think we're closer," Missouri coach Quin Snyder said. "We were in position to win a game on the road, but we didn't finish it. It's the same formula as at home, but it's harder." Roby led the Buffaloes with 15 points while Chris Copeland had 12 points and 11 rebounds. Jason Conley led Mizzou with 16 points. Teammate Linas Kleiza had 14 points on 4-for-17 shooting from the floor, a far cry from his 8-for-12, 31-point effort last weekend in a win over Nebraska. This game played out as one would expect from a meeting between two struggling teams desperate to stay out of the cellar in the Big 12. Neither shot particularly well or got into any kind of rhythm and nobody took a lead of more than seven points. But while the first 38 minutes were lackluster, the last two made for good drama. Leading 62-61 with about a minute left, Missouri's Thomas Gardner missed a shot but hustled back on defense and made a steal to get the ball back for the Tigers. He fed to Jimmy McKinney, but McKinney shot an airball with the shot clock running down. "I saw two guys come at me so I tried to get the ball up and hopefully hit the rim and have a chance to rebound the ball," McKinney said. Instead, Colorado got the rebound to set the stage for Roby, a 6-foot-6 guard out of San Bernardino, Calif., who chose Colorado over UCLA and a number of other high-profile programs. He has shown flashes of how good he can be throughout this season, averaging 14 points and five rebounds a game. This, however, was his biggest moment -- and now the Buffs are getting used to winning the tight ones toward the end. "It's good to know the good Lord is still in the miracle business," Patton said.
